text:
WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Kate Stirling
Address: Longley
Birthplace: Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1911
Where did you set up housekeeping? Longley
Where had you been living before that? At school in Alberta, Mont.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6 children and visitors
How far was it to your nearest store? 5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice a year
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
flour, sugar, dried fruit, light molasses called "black strap" substitute for syrup, rolled oats, coffee, tea

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Rapp
In what quantities did you buy it? 500 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No. How far away? _______ What year? _______
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? _______
What other grain products did you use? None
Cornmeal? None Whole wheat? None Farina? None
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? None
How did you grind it? None
1911 Stirling, Mrs. Kate

1. What year did you start homesteading in Eastern Canada? 1911.

2. What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?

3. In what quantities did you buy flour?

4. How much did you use per month?

5. Whole wheat flour?

6. Has flour milled locally?

7. That was the price for a twenty-pound bag of rolled oats?

8. Other flour products did you use?

9. Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?

10. How did you grind it?
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $8.00.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? N/A

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? N/A

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? N/A

Butter? N/A

What was the price of butter? N/A

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

What kind of cheese? N/A

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? N/A

How did you get fresh meat? N/A

How often did you get fresh meat? N/A

How did you preserve meat? Canned beef, salted

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No

If so what year was it organized? N/A

Did you use game? Yes

For how long? N/A

What part did fish play in the family diet? N/A

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh fish

Kinds? Black cod, white fish
2.

3. **BEANS AND PEAS**

What was the price for a ton? 

Was there any other variety? 

Did you buy them at the store? 

4. **DAIRY PRODUCTS**

How did you get your milk? 

What kind of cheese did you make? 

Did you make butter? 

Did you make eggs? 

5. **MEAT AND FISH**

What was your meat supply in the early years? 

How often did you get fresh meat? 

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? 

For how long? 

That part of the family diet was made up of what?

Was the meat cooked, white, or brown?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? ........................................ At what price? ...............
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) .............. Beans ..................
Price? .................................................. That other beverages were used? ..........
..............................................................................................................................

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
$1.00/bushel. Could you get potatoes at the store? ................. Yes ..................
If not, where from? .............................................................
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1911, Cabbage ......., Carrots ......., Onions .......
Turnips 1911, Beets .......
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? ................. 10 lbs ............
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? ................... Buy by the box ........
What weight? 20 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes ...........
What was the price of prunes? $8.4 ...........
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
Apples, apricots, peaches, raisins.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by Irving? .......... No ...........
Peas? No ....... corn? No ....... beans? No ....... Saskatoons? Yes .......
Other foods? Apples, pears, wild fruits ...........
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ............... 1911 ...........
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ........ 1935 ...........
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ............... 1935 ...........
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ................. Yes ...........
To what extent? Enough to last a year .....................
Did you make your own vinegar? No .........................
6. Buy goods:
   - What kind of tea did you buy?
   - At what price?
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground)
   - How much did you pay?

7. Vegetables and fruits purchased:
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel?
   - How many potatoes did you buy?
   - How much did they cost?
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the market?
   - What vegetables did you buy?
   - How did you buy prunes? (in bulk or by the box)?
   - How much did the grocer handle prunes for you?
   - What other dried fruits did you use in the market?
   - Apples, apricots, peaches, plums, raisins, currants, or others?

8. Other purchases:
   - In the early days, what did you buy?
   - Did you ever purchase any other goods?
   - What year did you first purchase fruit by canning?
   - What year did you first purchase vegetables by canning?
   - What year did you first purchase meat by canning?
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?
   - To what extent?
   - Did you make your own vinegar?

**10. Baking**

What type of yeast did you use? **Agarot**.

Did you make yeast for your own use? **No**.

Using starters? **No**.

Using hops? **No**.

Salt rising? **No**.

Baking soda? **Yes**.

Did you buy baking powder? **No**.

Grease or tallow? **No**.

Did you take your own baking powder? **No**.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ..................

How far was this water from your home? ...........................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In the spring of 1950 we dug a well beside the house and pumped it in to the sink otherwise we melted ice in a barrel in the house for winter use otherwise we hauled water in a barrel.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, spring, dugout).

If you got this water from your house? How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank, haul, and hand).

In the spring of 1920 we dug a well beside the house and pumped it in to the sink otherwise we melted ice in a barrel in the house for winter use otherwise we heated water in a barrel.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought soap.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Wood ashes.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

Since 1940 we have made our own laundry soap out of lye.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood and liquid coal.

Where did you get your fuel? Mine down our mountain, what is called Wood Pit, located 1/2 miles south.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We used liquid coal till about 1920 when we would buy coal when we could afford it then the depression of the 30's came and we used liquid coal almost exclusively till about 1940 when times picked up and we used coal again.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Majestic Mfg Co.

What year was it purchased? 1918. Price? $7.50.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron and iron.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China and earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? 1911.

Aluminum? 1925.
thoughts about...

13. SUGAR

14. FUEL

15. METAL

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or stove? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or stove? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove used?

That year was it purchased?

What type of stove did you use? (coal, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (cherry, earthware, modern bowls, other)

When did you start using aluminum?

When did you start using stainless steel?
Our foods were all bought in bulk outside of dried fruit in wooden boxes, dairies came in 5-gal. square tin cans with a tight sealing lid, and a few articles of food were wrapped in smaller 1-lb packages.

When we came to the country in 1920 our daily menu was oatmeal, mushy beefsteak, potatoes, dried fruit or molasses for breakfast, meat, potatoes, apple or dried fruit pie or rice and tapioca pudding for dinner, meat, potatoes, dried fruit and cake for supper.

Mother 38 yrs., brother 16 yrs., sister 14 yrs., myself 10 yrs.

Uncle 42 yrs.

What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

In about 1915 we served our first Christmas dinner. We served turkey, potatoes, pudding, apple and mince pie, mac cake, fruit, pickles, light cake.

Earl Nash 32 yrs. Robert Stirling 27 yrs. Josephine Stirling 25 yrs.
Mrs. Earl Nash 22 yrs. Mrs. Kate Stirling 25 yrs. Belma Stirling 25 yrs.
Miss Agnes Stirling 25 yrs. Raymond Stirling 19 yrs. Bachelor
George Stirling 40 yrs. Stewart Stirling 35 yrs. David Stirling 30 yrs.

Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on only locally produced foods? Give details.

It would be about the year 1930 that we were forced to ask for relief but got along with $10.50 to $12.50 a month with 3 and my husband and 4 children to feed but we didn't fare too badly for we had our meat and potatoes and cows and chickens prices at the local store were quite moderate at the time. I think the hardest task was trying to get enough surplus to buy a sack of flour which was only about $2.50 a hundred at the time, eggs bought as low as 10¢ a doz. and butter 10¢ a lb.
Our food was all bought in bulk outside
of dried fruit in wooden boxes. During
the war, sugar tin came with a tight
sealing lid partitioned packages.

When we came to the country in 1920 our daily
menu was oatmeal, mush, apples, potatoes, dried
fruit, molasses for breakfast, meatless potatoes, offal or
dried fruit, rice and gravy, building up dinner,
milk, potatoes, dried fruit, and cake the following day.

Mother was from northern New York, winter always being very cold.

In about 1915 we served our first Christmas dinner.

We served turkey, potatoes, stuffing, apple and onion pie,
gravy and sauce, puddings, hot and cold.

Mrs. Earl Marsh, 35 yrs., Mrs. Earl Marsh, 40 yrs.,
Miss Agnes Stebbins, 26 yrs., Miss Agnes Stebbins, 28 yrs.

It would be about the year 1930 that we were
found to be fairly but getting along with $10.50 to
$12.00 a month with 3 and my husband and 4
children to feed, but we didn't have too badly

For our food we had meat and potatoes and eggs
and chicken, brown rice at the local store were
quite moderate at the time. I think the
hard luck was trying to get enough to eat
to buy a sack of flour which was only about $2.50
a hundred at the time. Eggs brought a dollar
10¢ a day, and butter 10¢ a lb.
There are a great many recipes for dainty foods to eat, but they are still a luxury only for a change as the groceries are so high such as nuts, dates, currants, etc., but we have plenty of eggs on the farm. We could buy these articles in olden times easier than we can today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We were so busy up till about 1935 that we didn't raise a garden but up to that time we could buy canned vegetables quite reasonably but when we began raising a garden we canned plenty to do us for a year. Quite a few of the women in the country worked an outfit in the field so the garden became sadly neglected.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We lived so far from a railroad when we came to the country that we only made about two trips a year to the store for groceries. I remember one year specially that we lived on just 100% of food from the store but prices were so reasonable we seemed to have enough. In the olden days we all lived in log houses that were really comfortable in summer as well as winter. The logs were hauled with teams and wagons from the Cypress Hills which were about 5 miles from here. There were surface deposits of what is called white mud which lies over
We were so busy at that time that we didn't have a garden but by that time we could try our hand at it. We had a nice little garden and we raised plenty of vegetables and fruits. We also had a few chickens and a couple of cows.

We lived on farmland where we could roam freely and enjoy the outdoors. We had two acres of land and we lived there for many years. We raised crops and animals and we always had enough to eat.

In the olden days we all lived in big houses that were usually comfortable and warm even in the winter. We had a fireplace and we would sit around it and talk about our families from time to time. We were very close and we always looked out for each other.
about 40 miles from here towards the hills
and I would take a team and spring wagon
and get a few sacks of it to white wash the log
house which made it nice and clean again but
would rub off on our clothes if you leaned against
it. The logs were chinked with mud and pieces
of sod were laid on the boards for a roof and
sometimes would leak through when it rained.
The logs were infested with bed bugs which
were impossible to exterminate or get at them
they came with the logs from the hills. We would
have the occasional dance in the log house
with the harmonica and fiddle for music. There
were some half breeds living up in the hills that
played the fiddle and we would dance all night
for we were usually a long ways from home.
The half breeds were of French and Indian
origin and were quite complacent.
As food we were never short although we didn't
have very much money to spend it didn't seem
to take a great deal. We were quite a happy
contented lot but didn't have any luxuries.
When we came to the country the land wasn't
surveyed to about 10 miles north of us so our men
measured the distance by the revolutions of a wagon
wheel so we then fenced a pasture under what we
called squatters rights and it was pretty accurate
when the land was finally surveyed. Our cattle
ran at large and each rancher rode around his own
cattle every day to keep them from straying away
there were no fences only a pasture to keep the horses
we used.
I hope I have covered this record to the best of my
knowledge it is difficult to remember exactly but
think it is nearly correct. Mrs. Kate Sterling.
about 40 miles from there towards the hills and we would take a turn and driving wagon and get a few sacks of it to wash wash the by horses which made stoves and clean again but would not offer any of them a second again. The logs were chinked with mud and pine sometimes would leak through when strained. The logs were used for a roof and were impossible to get under or put them they came with the log from the hills. We would have the occasional dance in the big house with the harmonica and fiddle for music. There were some half-built living in the hills that played the fiddle and we would dance all night.

For our wives usually a long way from home. If she had been more of church and of prayer, and was quite content. After we were moved about although our eldest have very much money to spend it didn't seem to take a great deal nor were quite a happy contented lot but didn't have any luxuries.

When we came to the country the land wasn't surveyed to about 10 miles north of us so our own measured the distance by the surveying of a wagon wheel so we knew a pasture wouldn't be called a quarter right and it was pretty accurate when the land was finally surveyed. Our cattle run at large and each rancher took around his own cattle every day to keep them from straying away there were no fences only a pasture to keep the herds in mind.

I hope I have covered this record to the best of my knowledge it is difficult to remember exactly but think it is nearly correct. Miss. Hale of Indiana
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name Mrs. Kate B. Stirling
Address Laramie, Sask.
Birthplace Whatley, Mass., U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1911
Where did you set up housekeeping? 7 miles southwest of Laramie.
Where had you been living before that? 3 miles southeast, nearest home.
For how many people did you prepare meals? From 2 to 14 depending on work.
How far was it to your nearest store? 15 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
dried fruit, sugar, tea, coffee, tapioca, rice flour and common necessary needs.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robin Hood and White Rose.
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. bags.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50.
How much did you use graham flour? A very little.
Whole wheat flour? None.
Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? .......... What year? 1912.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...........
What other grain products did you use? Corn meal.
Cornmeal? .............. Whole Wheat? None. Farina? None.
Other? None.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.
How did you grind it? ...........................................

6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose... At what price? $3.50
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground
Price? $1.40 each. What other beverages were used? None

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $1.00
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from? None
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1912, Cabbage 1916, Carrots 1918, Onions 1915,
Turnips 1915, Beets 1915.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 5 lbs.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box
What weight? 20 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? By the pound
What was the price of prunes? $1.00
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
Apples, apricots, peaches and raisins.

8. PRESERVING

Peas? No, corn? No, beans? No, Saskatoons? No
Other foods? No

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1916
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1935
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1940

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?
I still can meat and pickles but no vegetables
To what extent? Very little

Did you make your own vinegar? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ...River...

How far was this water from your home? ...2 a.m. up the road...

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ...pail and barrel...

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We dug a well just outside the house and pumped it into the end of the sink so have a generous water supply. We sent a sample in to be tested and there were no impurities in the water.

12. Water supply

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, dugout)

If so far was this water from your house? If not, was it brought to the house by (pail, barrel, tank) paid and travel

Was drinking water supply rationed any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

First started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

The dug a well just outside the house and pumped it into the end of the sink so here a generous water supply. We don't have any impurities in the water to be tested and there were no impurities in the water.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought laundry soap.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Wood ashes.

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? None.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal and wood.

Where did you get your fuel? Dried poles from the Cypress Hills 37 miles away and lignite coal own mined 2 miles away.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

When a railroad was built past Bonanza a good grade of coal was shipped in by the carload at about $6.00 a ton; that would be about 1915 so we bought our coal until the depression of the 30s then we would mine some lignite.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron and tin.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China and earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? Before 1912.

Aluminum? Before 1912.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Tea and coffee are done up in containers instead of paper wrappings like they used to be in bulk. We didn't get tin containers till about 1915. The quality was much better than than now and cheaper.

I don't see much difference in the containers.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Before I was married with my mother and brother when I was 18 yrs., my brother 16 yrs. and mother 31 yrs. for breakfast - oatmeal mush, beefsteak, potatoes, sour dough pancakes - for dinner meat, potatoes, pie or bread pudding - for supper meat, potatoes, dried fruit and cake. My brother had a huge appetite as noticeable by the menu for breakfast.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu, list those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Menu for Anna's dinner consisted of roast chicken, mashed potatoes, pickles, a canned vegetable (timed) cake.

Isaac Stirling 35 yrs. Mrs. Kate Stirling 25 yrs.
Agnes Stirling 30 yrs. Earl Nash 28 yrs.
Mrs. E. Nash (mother) 43 yrs. And odd bachelors that had no home near them.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

When the depression came in the 30s we were on relief for a few years and it was hard to manage the household on $10.50 a month sometimes food was very scarce but we managed to get enough to eat. I think the hardest task was to be out enough to buy a sack of flour for the small amount of relief only covered the smaller needs. I sold some butter and eggs, butter at 10¢ a lb. and eggs @ 4¢ each which was down to the lowest price, a crate of eggs would bring 48¢ which wouldn't buy many groceries.
Before I was married with my mother and brother when I was 16 years old, my brothers and sisters were very young.

At breakfast, we had oatmeal mush, toast, bacon, and eggs. For dinner, we had roast chicken, mashed potatoes, pickles, and canned vegetables (tomatoes). We also had applesauce for dessert.

When the depression came in the 30s, we were in relief for a few years and it was hard to manage the household. We had to economize and save money but we managed to get enough to eat. We tried to save money by buying a sack of flour for the small amount of flour only covered the smaller meals. We would save butter and eggs, but not at all, and eggs etc., which were down to the lowest price a crate of eggs would bring.

I don't see much difference in the containers.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

We cooked and prepared our meals in the same way as today comparing the common foods we didn't have any luxuries. We didn't have fruit and vegetable salads like we have today but sometimes had potato salad. My mother would boil corn beef and cabbage which was a luxury those days.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We didn't raise a garden until about 1940 when I came quite a quantity of vegetables up till then we depended on prepared foods from the store although we didn't use them extravagantly. We used quite a lot of macaroni with cheese or tomatoes. When the farmers settled in this district they worked up garden patches but didn't have too much success for some time. Plant life doesn't do too well in this southern part of Saskatchewan.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above; quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

We have turned this district into mixed farming for we seem to be in a dry belt our rainfall is very sparse outside of our 10-year cycle when we will have about two rainy years enough to produce a crop to about 25 bushels an acre. Cattle raising seems to be the mainstay but grain production provides straw for stock in the winter. There are very few horses left as everything is mechanized. We need to drive a team and wagon over 50 miles of prairie to Chinook and Shaunavon and get some of our groceries which were cheaper than at our own place.
We worked hard and harvested our own vegetables in the same way we today consume the common foods we didn't have any vegetables. We didn't have potatoes or tomatoes but sometimes had potato salad. My mother would boil corn by hand, cabbage which was a luxury these days.

Then all you bought to buy on purchased foods until my parents forced me to eat them. (Give us many details and facts)

We did not have a garden until about 1940 when I learned how to grow vegetables. Although we didn't need them, extravagantly we used up a lot of vegetables with cheese and tomatoes. Then the farmers settled in this district they worked up gardens quickly.

But didn't have to mind because for some time plants didn't do well in this northern part of Idaho.

Plants and other details from your early experiences of buying vegetables.

Include dates not mentioned, locations, names, and other details. (Use back of book)

We have turned this district into mixed farming for wet season to be in a dry belt our rainfall is very sparse outside of our 10-year cycle where we will have about two rainy years enough to produce a crop to about 25 pounds an acre. Both raising animals to be the mainstay but grain production provides straw for stock in the winter. There are very few horses left as everything is mechanized.

The need to drive a team and wagon over 30 miles of prairie to plow and harvest than at our place of our previous which were cheaper than at our place.
own towns. We would make the trip once or twice a year; there were no customs then.

When we came to the country the land wasn't surveyed from about 15 miles north of us to the American border south. My Uncle and brother took a team and spring wagon and measured the location of the land we took as squatters rights by counting the revolutions on one of the buggy wheels and when the land was at last surveyed their measurements were nearly correct.

We bought our first car in 1916 and would purchase some of our groceries there but by that time there was a local store to do our needs.

In early days we would buy a 5-gal. can of kerosene and if it didn't last we used other methods. My mother would fill a small dish with rendered beef tallow and put a small roll of white cotton rag in the center and light it at night to see to read by. It would make quite an odor in the room this would happen in the winter time if we happened to get short of oil and it was 50 miles to the nearest town.
own town. We would make the trip twice a year—there were no autos then.

When we came to the country the land wasn't surveyed from about 16 miles north of me to the American border south. My Uncle and brother took a team and spring wagon and measured the location of the land we took as squatters rights by counting the rungs on our of the buggy wheel and when the land was at least surveyed their measurements were nearly correct.

We bought our first car in 1916 and would purchase some of our groceries there but by that time there was a local store to do our needs.

In early days we would buy a 5 gal. can of kerosene and if it didn't last we used other methods. My mother would fill a small dish with rendered tallow and put a small roll of white cotton rag in the center and light it at night to see to read by.

It would make quite an odor in the room this would happen in the winter time if we happened to get short of oil and it was 50 miles to the nearest town.
